awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dimensions US-BIOTA-Sao Paulo: Scales of biodiversity-Integrated studies of snake venom evolution and function across multiple levels of diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will determine how key innovations within the venom system have contributed to diversification in the 2,500 species of advanced snakes. Venom is hypothesized to have been the key innovation initiating the evolutionary radiation of snake species by expanding feeding opportunities. This project will seek to determine the factors and traits that promoted that diversification, and will test for biases in the genetic pathways underlying rapid evolution in venoms between closely related species. The study includes the training of two postdoctoral researchers, and multiple high school, undergraduate, and graduate students at three major state universities in Ohio and Florida. The research will produce new data on venom chemistry and function, which may be useful for novel drug discovery and design.

Representative samples of diverse species from three families of venomous snakes will be collected in the United States, Central America, and Brazil to test for relationships between venom function and diversification rates. Venom complexity, composition, and enzymatic-activity profiles will be assayed to test the hypothesis that higher venom evolvability is a prerequisite for rapid evolutionary diversification. Six closely related species pairs with highly divergent venoms will be chosen for molecular assays to evaluate the genetic and protein changes responsible for rapid evolution of venom function. This work will unite diversification studies and the genetics of adaptation to provide an integrated perspective of how adaptations are built and how they affect diversification, leading to an understanding of how biodiversity originates across micro- to macroevolutionary levels.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding origins and patterns of biodiversity is a major theme in evolutionary biology. Historically, this theme was investigated by studying individual species and specific morphological traits. More recently, researchers have embraced genomic approaches to investigate multidimensional suites of traits across vast phylogenetic scales. Many ecological and evolutionary impactful traits facilitate the evolution of biodiversity and are therefore prime targets for studying the processes generating biodiversity. Venoms have evolved independently over one hundred times across the tree of life and are central to the biology of species that wield them. The advanced snakes (superfamily Colubroidea) are comprised of more than 2,500 species derived from an ancestor with at least a rudimentary venom and account for the majority of commonly seen snakes. This group contains the front-fanged venomous snakes such as vipers (e.g., rattlesnakes) and elapids (e.g., cobras), as well as other species with enlarged rear fangs and venoms generally regarded as largely harmless to humans. To understand the evolution of snake biodiversity, we collected and characterized hundreds of snakes across the New World to investigate how the acquisition and subsequent evolution of venom impacts the evolution of snake diversity. Our overarching goal was to assess how venom characteristics contributed to the evolution of snake biodiversity.

To achieve this goal, we generated vast quantities of venom proteomic data, venom-gland transcriptomic data, and snake whole-genome sequences. In total, this project sequenced whole genomes of more than 12 venomous snake species and characterized venom-gland transcriptomes and venom proteomes of more than 1,000 individual snakes to understand the evolution of venom and the biodiversity of snakes. Using a phylogenetic framework, we estimated the evolutionary histories of species and related these to patterns of venom complexity and composition. We showed that venom complexity evolves in response to the phylogenetic diversity of prey species consumed by the snakes, rather than simple species richness. We argue that this pattern reflects phylogenetic divergence in the physiological targets of the venom. This study focused on rattlesnakes as a model, which allowed us to also infer the first, nearly complete, rattlesnake tree of life. Additionally, we determined that multiple molecular mechanisms are significant contributors to venom variation across species, including venom gene sequence evolution, gene duplication, gene deletion, and gene-expression changes. The genetic mechanisms involved in venom evolution are surprisingly diverse, which likely facilitates their rapid evolutionary responses to changing selective pressures. Competition is a critical selective force for diversification. We, therefore, used our extensive data to test the effect of competition on the evolution of pitviper venoms. Pitvipers represent a cross-continental radiation of venomous snakes, each expressing tens to hundreds of individual toxins with substantial variation in expression, composition, and overall complexity among species. We found that pitviper communities have evolved to maximize functional diversity despite comparatively low phylogenetic diversity, suggesting an evolutionary response of venom rather than communities accumulating phylogenetically diverse species.

This project involved substantial international collaboration. Initially, the research team was comprised of scientists from Brazil and the U.S. The project ultimately required collaboration between scientists from Brazil, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Mexico, and the U.S. The project also facilitated many broader impacts, including training of graduate students, undergraduates, and postdoc doctoral scholars, international collaboration among research teams, outreach to the general public in both Brazil and the U.S., and communication of research results to the scientific community. Undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral training emphasized field-to-lab-to-computer research, with team members each actively engaged in collecting efforts, molecular bench work, and bioinformatic analysis of proteomic, transcriptomic, and genomic data. Several international exchanges of students, postdocs, and CoPIs occurred among our collaborative teams, engendering new collaborations and revealing new avenues for future research. CoPIs, postdocs, and their students have given numerous presentations at meetings in the U.S. and South America to present the results of their work on this project. Finally, many public outreach events were carried out both in the U.S. and Brazil, although the COVID-19 pandemic impacted our ability to engage with the public.
